title: If the universe is infinite, does that mean there is an infinite number of 'me'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Question: If the universe is infinite, does that mean there is an infinite number of “me”? Answer: It doesn’t. No. However, it also doesn’t preclude the possibility. But it also rather depends on what you mean by ‘infinite’ and by ‘me’. Your question is a great one for debate in a philosophy class. Unfortunately Quora is a great site, but it isn’t really structured for debate. Infinity is a tricky concept, not least because there are degrees of infinity. For example, there are an infinite number of countable positive integers. And there are an infinite but uncountable number of rational numbers between zero and one. Aleph 1 infinity is greater than aleph null. Don’t even try wrapping your head around the higher alephs of the transfinite numbers. And infinity is all too often confused with unbounded, which is very similar in most regards, but … not quite the same thing. So if there are an infinite number of billiard balls in the universe, each bearing a seperate positive integer on it - 1, 2, 3 , 4 …. etc to infinity, then you do have an infinite universe with an infinite number of billiard balls in it, but each billiard ball is just a billiard ball - limited, individual, distinct. No billiard ball is infinite. But then - you are not a billiard ball. It is certainly true in a multi-verse that there are an infinite number of almost identical universes / versions of the universe which would include an infinite (although infinitely lesser number) of versions of you. But strictly speaking a multi-verse refers to an infinite number of universes, rather than an infinite universe. And if that confuses you (which is entirely understandable) you probably need to do a little research into definitions of ‘the universe’, and study concepts of infinity, which will require you to look into maths a bit. What I suspect the question is alluding to is the idea that “in a truly infinite universe anything that can happen must happen”, which includes the idea that there must be an infinite number of similar Earths populated with almost identical people, history etc., including infinite people genetically and nurtured identically to ‘Me’. Logically, that does have to be true. It also requires the universe to be a particular kind of infinity with an infinite amount of matter in it remaining in some sort of steady state configuration. This is very very VERY different to a universe of finite mass with unbounded spacial dimensions, which is also sometimes confusingly referred to as infinite. It is possible we live in the unbounded version. We currently have no evidence that we live in a Universe with infinite mass. But even in an infinite steady state universe with all these parallel worlds this doesn’t exactly yield an infinite number of ‘Me”. Apart from being identical to ‘Me’ in every way these person’s have nothing whatsoever in common with “Me”. That may sound confusing, but it is true. They are simply identical to ‘Me’, but that apart they have nothing in common with ‘Me’ at all. Each can make it’s own decisions and go its own path. They will never meet me, communicate with me, or be aware of me in any way, thanks to the limitation of the speed of light. They may technically be part of the same infinite universe as ‘Me’, but they are not part of the same observable universe as ‘Me’. That word ‘observable’ makes universes of difference, quite literally in this case. Or, stated another way - we are into a question of definition of ‘Me’. See why this really needs a debate forum rather than Quora? Fredrick Pohl wrote a lovely Sci-Fi story about the ‘Me’ problem once. In the story some form of tachyon transmission and replication had been created. So I could step into a scanner on Earth, and then walk out of the scanner unchanged, still ‘Me’. Meantime the scanner broke everything about ‘Me’ down into some sort of digital signal and transmitted it faster than light to a receiver on some distant world (lets call it Hades) which used the signal with a replicator to rebuild an exact copy of ‘Me’. That ‘Me’ then stepped out onto a world like HELL still undergoing terraforming. What did that ‘Me’ do. It immediately hated and swore vengeance against the ‘Me’ back on Earth, still enjoying the good comfortable life who had condemned this other ‘Me’ to a life of torment on Hades. Of course the ‘Me’ on Hades could never even meet the ‘Me’ on Earth. But what it could and did do was walk into a scanner on Hades and send a tachyon stream back to Earth which went into a replicator and produced another copy of ‘Me’ on Earth, sworn to revenge against the first ‘Me’ on Earth. This is the ‘Me’ problem. It is also evidence that the light speed barrier may be a blessing, because at present there is no evidence that tachyons exist, or that the light speed barrier can be broken, or that my Quantum state can be digitised for transmission (Dan Simmons has great fun with this). So hopefully you will never meet one of your other ‘You’s. But if you do, you will realise that an identical ‘Me’ is no more ‘Me’ than an identical twin brother is ‘Me’. As I said, it’s a wonderful question for a debate forum, but in the context of Quora this highly inadequate answer is about the best I can do. Hope it helps.

There’s a couple of ways (at least) that you can mean “infinite” universe. We’ll call them the classical and quantum views. — In either case the universe has a cosmic horizon. Beyond that horizon spacetime is expanding (ref: metric expansion) faster than the speed of light; that means it has moved out of causal contact with you. We can’t know what’s going on there; so, if you want to say there are pink elephants and dragons and unicorns there — at least from this vantage point I’m at now — I can’t falsify those assertions. If you want to say there is a copy of you outside the visible universe, I can’t falsify that. — If you want to get down to the quantum view, then we need to ask do you mean an infinite number of “yous” at this point in time; or, an infinite number of yous over some course of time. Yes, there are infinite number of yours over some course of time. That, really, is a classical or quantum thought. — If you’re wanting multiple coexistent yous, within the visible universe, then you’ve got a potential issue with a postulated prohibition against creating exact quantum copies. So, this would have to be a naturally occurring instance. Given a ridiculous amount of time, nothing prevents two of yous from coming about; you may recur after  years, give or take an order of magnitude. But, that’s still not the probability (or occurrence rate) of two of yous. I’m still going to say that quantum information cannot occur in two places simultaneously. You’ll need multiverse theory for that; and, by definition, that’s not existing in the same universe. Multiverse theory is different from being outside the causal boundary of our “visible” universe. → Shifting your vantage point would shift the causal boundary in the classical theory (and, that’s real stuff — I can falsify that). On the other hand, you can’t shift between parallel universes in multiverse theory; yet another way of saying no two yous will ever be in the same universe. — So, the answer to your question is Yes, it’s possible that you will recur; yes, it’s possible that you occur in different “universes.” I don’t think it’s going to be allowed that two of yous coexist in the same universe.

There is no reason to think so. Given the vast amount of randomness that goes into every moment of your life it is not even likely in a nearly identical universe. Until one knows the rules for building universes the question can’t be rationally answered. All of the people who say “yes” have some particular model of how universes come to be that they assume is the only one. They don’t detail their model or explain how such exactness of events that led up to you could come about. The only way to ensure that another universe has someone that is just like you is for that universe to be just like this one down to the position of every particle. The nature of our universe is that you can’t enumerate those values so it is meaningless to discuss how they could be repeated.

Of course! Which tells you how absurd infinity is when asserted about reality. Not only that—an infinite universe implies an infinite number of intelligent brains floating in it, called Bolzmann brains, each randomly formed out of atoms in its environment that happened to bump into each other. The absurdity goes even further if we assume the univese is also infinitely old. For then the night sky would have to be as bright as the surface of the sun (Olbers' paradox) and the universal entropy would be already maximized (a dead universe.) Infinity is an indispensable concept in mathematics and poetry, maybe also in philosophy and theology, but untenable in physics and in relating to reality.

the idea of an infinite number of universes is a very weak and silly idea. and you have put your finger on one of the very silly features of such a notion. yes, if there were an infinite number of universes there would have to be an infinite number of everyone, including you, me and donald trump. incidentally, the idea of an infinite number of universes has nothing to do with science. it’s philosophy and poor philosophy at that!

If there are (and there are not) an infinite amount of universes, every possible variation of a universe exists and is repeated an infinite number of times. Such is the nature of infinity. So there are an infinite number of you-universes exactly like this one, an infinite number of universes that vary a bit or a lot with you in them (with you staying the same and the universe varying, or others with you varying a bit or a lot), each repeated an infinite number of times, and an infinite number of universes without you at all, each variation repeated an infinite number of times. But there’s no evidence that this is the case, so I wouldn’t worry about it. Even if it’s true, and we’ll never know, I wouldn’t worry about it.

No, because any possible infinity of universes would be of aleph-1 strength, whereas the infinite number of options that led to the existence of you (the infinity of alternatives at many nodes of the chain of events that led to you) has an aleph-2 metric, and therefore the likelihood of another you existing within an aleph-1 multitude of universes is equal to aleph-1 divided by aleph-2, i.e. as close to zero as can be without actually being nil.
